title: 105_s1907
content: REFUNDABLE CREDIT FOR WETLAND RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION EXPENSES: Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new section on wetland restoration and conservation expenses. The tax code allows eligible taxpayers to claim a credit for wetland restoration, conservation, and easement expenses. The wetland restoration credit is based on expenditures paid or incurred by the taxpayer in a taxable year. The wetland restoration credit allows eligible taxpayers to claim a credit for wetland restoration expenditures paid or incurred in a taxable year. This includes expenditures for the restoration of farmed or prior converted wetlands to fully functioning wetland condition. The term 'wetland restoration expenditure' refers to expenses for restoring farmed or prior converted wetlands to fully functioning condition, as per an approved restoration plan by the Natural Resources Conservation Service. These expenses must be paid or incurred within the first 5 years of a qualified conservation agreement or easement. The wetland conservation credit is an amount equal to the sum of the applicable percentage of the soil-specific Conservation Reserve Program rental rate. It does not include expenditures required by Federal or State law. The wetland conservation credit for any taxable year includes the applicable percentage of the soil-specific Conservation Reserve Program rental rate and any fee for certification of compliance paid by the eligible taxpayer. The wetland conservation credit for a taxable year includes the applicable percentage of the Conservation Reserve Program rental rate and any fee for compliance certification paid by the eligible taxpayer. The applicable percentage is determined based on the term of the qualified conservation agreement entered into by the taxpayer. The wetland conservation credit for a taxable year is determined by the applicable percentage based on the term of the qualified conservation agreement. The applicable percentages range from 50% to 70% depending on the length of the agreement. The wetland conservation credit is determined by the length of the conservation agreement, ranging from 50% to 70%. If a taxpayer elects a wetland easement credit, the conservation credit for that wetland is zero. The wetland conservation credit is zero if a taxpayer elects for a qualified wetland under subsection (d). The wetland easement credit allows eligible taxpayers to receive fair market value for qualified wetlands under a conservation easement. The wetland easement credit allows taxpayers to receive fair market value for qualified wetlands under a conservation easement, determined by a certified appraisal during the taxable year. An election under this subsection applies to the taxable year for which it is made. The wetland easement credit allows eligible taxpayers to receive fair market value for qualified wetlands under a conservation easement, as determined by a certified appraisal during the taxable year. An election under this subsection applies to the taxable year for which it is made. The wetland easement credit allows eligible taxpayers to receive fair market value for qualified wetlands under a conservation easement, as determined by a certified appraisal during the taxable year. An eligible taxpayer owns wetlands, farmed wetlands, or prior converted wetlands, along with surrounding actively farmed cropland, and has entered into a qualified conservation agreement or easement. The wetland easement credit allows eligible taxpayers to receive fair market value for qualified wetlands under a conservation easement. An eligible taxpayer owns wetlands, farmed wetlands, or prior converted wetlands, along with surrounding actively farmed cropland, and has entered into a qualified conservation agreement or easement. A qualified wetland is defined as wetland, including farmed wetland or prior converted wetland, which is being restored through wetland restoration expenditures. The wetland easement credit allows eligible taxpayers to receive fair market value for qualified wetlands under a conservation easement. A qualified wetland is wetland being converted to fully functioning condition through restoration expenditures, as determined by a qualified conservation agreement or easement. The wetland easement credit allows taxpayers to receive fair market value for qualified wetlands under a conservation easement. Qualified wetlands are those being converted to fully functioning condition through restoration expenditures, as determined by a qualified conservation agreement or easement. Surrounding nonwetland areas can also be included in the agreement to buffer water quality or wildlife habitat values associated with the wetland, as long as the nonwetland acreage does not exceed 3 times the wetland acreage. The wetland easement credit allows taxpayers to receive fair market value for qualified wetlands under a conservation easement. Nonwetland areas can be included in the agreement to buffer water quality or wildlife habitat values associated with the wetland, as long as the nonwetland acreage does not exceed 3 times the wetland acreage. The wetland easement credit allows taxpayers to receive fair market value for qualified wetlands under a conservation easement. Nonwetland areas can be included in the agreement to buffer water quality or wildlife habitat values associated with the wetland, as long as the nonwetland acreage does not exceed 3 times the wetland acreage. Certain property excluded from the wetland acreage includes land with contract or easement payments received from conservation programs. Wetland, farmed wetland, and prior converted wetland are terms defined by the Food Security Act of 1985. The Food Security Act of 1985 defines wetland, farmed wetland, and prior converted wetland. A qualified conservation agreement is an agreement with a governmental unit for a term of at least 10 years. "A qualified conservation agreement is an agreement with a governmental unit for a term of 10-30 years where the taxpayer agrees to comply with conservation requirements for a qualified wetland." The taxpayer must comply with conservation requirements for a qualified wetland in a 10-30 year agreement and obtain certification of compliance every 5 years. The taxpayer must comply with conservation requirements for a qualified wetland in a 10-30 year agreement and obtain certification of compliance every 5 years. Compliance includes not using the wetland for agricultural production and refraining from draining, dredging, filling, or manipulating the wetland. The taxpayer must comply with conservation requirements for a qualified wetland, including not using it for agricultural production or manipulating it in ways that affect water flow. The term 'qualified conservation easement' refers to an easement granted in perpetuity by the taxpayer to restrict the use of a qualified wetland for agricultural production or development, ensuring it is preserved for conservation purposes. The term 'qualified conservation easement' refers to an easement granted in perpetuity by the taxpayer to restrict the use of a qualified wetland for conservation purposes, as defined in section 170(h). No credit is allowed for expenses that are already eligible for deduction or credit under other tax provisions. No double benefit is allowed for expenses eligible for deduction or credit under other tax provisions. Married couples must file joint returns for the conservation easement credit. No credit allowed if funds received from government programs. Married couples must file joint returns for the conservation easement credit. Amendments made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code. The taxpayer must be a married individual filing a joint return with their spouse for this section to apply. Amendments were made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1998.
